prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for wanting their girlfriend to start paying some bills after a single incident. The situation is that they live together, she works part-time, and he pays all the rent and bills. The incident was a $40 takeout when he forgot his wallet. She had an ugly attitude, acting disgusted and put out.

First, I need to figure out if the author is being reasonable. He's upset about a one-time event where she was supposed to pay for takeout but reacted negatively. The key points here are the arrangement between them and how he's handling it. He states he pays everything, but now he's angry and wants her to start contributing more. 

I should consider the context of their relationship. They live together, so sharing expenses is common, but the author hasn't asked her to contribute before. The issue is whether a single incident justifies changing the financial arrangement. Typically, splitting bills is a mutual agreement, and if she's only part-time, maybe she can't afford much. But the author is now using this one event to demand she start paying, which might be unfair. 

The question is about the author's right to do this. If he's been okay with paying everything until now, maybe he's been making assumptions. The $40 incident might have made him realize he wants a different arrangement, but acting unilaterally without discussing could be the problem. The author is in the wrong if they haven't communicated their expectations beforehand. 

Also, reacting over a small amount after one incident might be disproportionate. Relationships require communication and understanding. Instead of punishing her with bill payments, he should talk about his feelings and maybe adjust contributions gradually. 

So, the answer would be A (Yes, the author is in the wrong) because he's making a significant change based on a single event without prior discussion and possibly without considering her financial situation.
